Fig. 1 X-ray powder diffraction analysis of the parent MFI zeolite, impregnated VAMFI, impregnated VBMFI, and commercial V2O5. Fig. 2 Raman spectra of vanadium precursors, VAMFI, VBMFI, and commercial V2O5. Fig. 3 (A and C) X-ray absorption spectra in the XANES region for the K-edge energy of vanadium during calcination of MFI zeolites impregnated with vanadium precursors (VOSO4 and NH4VO3) from room temperature to 500°C; (B and D) speciation of vanadium-based phases obtained by linear combination fits of XANES spectra. Fig. 4 Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms (filled and empty points correspond to nitrogen adsorption and desorption, respectively). Fig. 5 (A) EXAFS signals and (B) corresponding Fourier transforms of the EXAFS signals recorded for the fully calcined V2O5, VAMFI, and VBMFI samples. Fig. 6 Temperature-programmed desorption profiles of adsorbed ammonia. Fig. 7 Effect of vanadium insertion method, atmosphere, and temperature on glycerol conversion and product selectivity. Fig. 8 Thermogravimetric curves obtained under an air atmosphere for fresh commercial V2O4 and V2O5, and for V2O5 after 1h of use in the glycerol oxidehydration reaction. Fig. 9 XPS spectra of V 2p3/2 in VAMFI: Fresh, spent, and catalyst re-oxidized at 350°C under air.Sat. stands for the satellite peaks. Fig. 10 Conversion of glycerol, main products selectivity, and selectivity towards condensable products of the VAMFI and parent MFI catalysts during 8h of reaction at 300°C. Fig. 11 (A) Thermogravimetric, (B) DTG, and (C) DTA curves of the spent catalysts. Fig. 12 13C MAS NMR spectra of the spent VAMFI catalyst in different temperatures. Graphical abstract The catalytic behavior of bifunctional V2O5/MFI catalysts with acid and oxidizing properties was investigated for the gas-phase oxidehydration of glycerol. One of the main reaction products was acrylic acid, produced by dehydration of glycerol to acrolein at an acidic site and subsequent oxidation at a redox site. Comparison of wet impregnation with vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4) and ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) showed that VOSO4 impregnation provided the best performance for the conversion of glycerol and selectivity towards acrylic acid. The chemical and structural properties of the catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, temperature programmed ammonia desorption, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy in the XANES region for the K-edge absorption of vanadium. XPS measurements of the fresh and spent catalysts enabled elucidation of the dynamic redox cycles of vanadium oxide during oxidation of acrolein. The presence of vanadium in the zeolite improved the catalyst lifetime, because of the multifunctional ability of the vanadium oxide species to convert acrolein to acrylic acid and act as co-catalyst for the oxidation of coked glycerol products. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of the coke deposited in the spent catalysts were performed using 13C NMR and thermogravimetry, respectively. Keywords Glycerol oxidehydration Acrolein Acrylic acid Bifunctional catalysts Zeolite Vanadium oxide 1 Introduction In recent years, increased production of biodiesel from transesterification of renewable feedstocks such as vegetable oils has led to the co-generation of vast quantities of glycerol. The challenge is to transform glycerol into more valuable products in order to improve the economics of biodiesel production and, at the same time, provide industry with various important chemicals [1]. To this end, glycerol oxidehydration is potentially one of the reactions that can be used, and acrylic acid is one of the main target products. Acrylic acid and its ester derivatives are the principal raw materials used in the manufacture of polymeric products that have many different applications. These polymers offer unique combinations of features such as colorless transparency, easy adhesion, elasticity, and stability towards light. Currently, more than 3 million tons per year of acrylic acid are produced by the petrochemical industry, using the two-step gas-phase oxidation of propylene [2]. It is therefore highly desirable to be able to synthesize acrylic acid by means of an integrated renewable route that minimizes the use of petrochemical resources as raw materials. Glycerol oxidehydration can be conceived as proceeding in two steps (Scheme 1 ). In the first step, glycerol is dehydrated to 3-hydroxypropanal, a very reactive intermediate that readily dehydrates to acrolein [1]. The second step is the selective oxidation of acrolein in the presence of molecular oxygen to yield acrylic acid [3–7]. For the first step of Scheme 1, various acid catalysts have been studied for the dehydration of glycerol, including MeO-Al2O3-PO4 (Me stands for transition metal) [8], WO3/TiO2 [9], and zeolites with different Si/Al molar ratios, such as MFI, BEA, FAU, and MOR structures [10]. Although acid zeolites have been identified as active catalysts for the production of acrolein, fast catalyst deactivation by deposition of non-reactive polyaromatic compounds that obstruct the micropores is a major problem that needs to be overcome. Quantities of carbonaceous species up to 30wt.% can be deposited during glycerol dehydration catalyzed by an acid zeolite with MFI structure [11]. For the second step of Scheme 1, a redox catalyst is needed. Vanadium oxides have a very important redox characteristic in catalysis due to the capacity to adopt multiple oxidation states. This is the basis of the manufacture of several chemicals, such as the synthesis of sulfuric acid by catalytic oxidation of SO2. The advantage of using vanadium-based oxides for acrolein oxidation in the presence of molecular oxygen is that an oxidative atmosphere, in combination with the redox properties of the vanadium oxides, is selective towards acrylic acid and effective for inhibiting the deposition of carbonaceous and non-volatile compounds [12–22]. However, in order to be efficiently used in the one-step glycerol oxidehydration, vanadium oxides need to have their properties altered by the incorporation of other additives. For example, the preparation of vanadium/tungsten mixed oxides enhances the acid properties of the catalyst and therefore diminishes the rate-limiting glycerol dehydration. As a second example, vanadium/molybdenum mixed oxides can enhance the catalytic activity because the combination of both elements facilitates the dynamic changes of V5+/V4+ oxidation states during catalytic reaction by the Mars–Van-Krevelen mechanism. These examples illustrate some of the reasons for research concerning the synthesis of complex oxides based on vanadium, which could act as efficient multifunctional catalysts for glycerol oxidehydration. Vanadium pyrophosphate oxides were investigated in a series of studies conducted by Ueda [23–26] and López Nieto [27,28], and V/W mixed oxides with hexagonal tungsten bronze structure, as well as V/W/Nb mixed oxides, have been used in one-step glycerol oxidehydration [29]. The combination of these two reaction steps in a single bifunctional (redox and acid) catalytic bed could offer several advantages for glycerol conversion to acrylic acid. For instance, an optimal thermal balance could be provided by coupling of the exothermic oxidation reaction with the endothermic dehydration reaction [7]. Furthermore, the combination of both acid and oxidizing sites should make it possible to achieve continuous oxidation of undesired dehydration byproducts. In a publication of 2013, the production of acrylic acid from glycerol oxidehydration using vanadium impregnated on an acid zeolite with BEA structure was mentioned for the first time [30]. Despite the importance of the findings, only very few aspects of the catalyst performance were explored. Aiming to contribute to the identification and understanding of efficient catalysts for glycerol conversion, the present work evaluates an acidic zeolite with MFI structure, impregnated using vanadium oxide. The characteristics of this zeolitic catalyst are explored using a combination of physico-chemical techniques: XRD, nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, NH3-TPD, XANES in the region of vanadium K-edge absorption, XPS, 13C NMR, and thermogravimetry. It is shown that the presence of vanadium oxides near the zeolite acid sites inhibits the formation of carbonaceous species by the oxidation of reactive carbon monomers before they oligomerize and block the active sites. The multifunctional feature of this catalyst enabled long-term control of the balance between the production of acrylic acid and the avoidance of carbon deposition, features that should contribute to integrated glycerol chemistry. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts The MFI zeolite (Si/Al molar ratio=40) in the ammonium form, kindly provided by Zeolyst, was initially used as received. The vanadium precursors, VOSO4 (V4+) and NH4VO3 (V5+), and vanadium oxides (V2O3, V2O4, and V2O5) were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich. The vanadium oxide-impregnated MFI zeolites were obtained by wet impregnation of the zeolite using aqueous solutions of either VOSO4 or NH4VO3 (0.05mol/L). The mixtures were stirred for 1h at room temperature, followed by water removal in a rotary evaporator and calcination of the catalyst precursor at 500°C for 2h under an air flow, resulting in V2O5 supported on a protonic MFI zeolite. The volume of the solution of the vanadium precursor was calculated in order to give a constant V/Al molar ratio of 5.5. The zeolites impregnated with VOSO4 and NH4VO3 were denoted VAMFI and VBMFI, respectively. Pure vanadium oxide samples, denoted V2O5-A and V2O5-B, were prepared by thermal decomposition (at 500°C) of the VOSO4 and NH4VO3 precursors, respectively. 2.2 Characterization of the catalysts The crystalline phases present in the calcined catalysts were analyzed by X-ray diffraction using a Siemens D5000 diffractometer, with Cu Kα radiation selected by a curved graphite monochromator. Data were collected in the 2θ range from 5 to 40°, using a step size of 0.01° and a counting time of 4s. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded at liquid nitrogen temperature, within a relative pressure interval of 0.001–0.998, using a Micromeritics instrument (Model ASAP 2010). Prior to the measurements, the samples were evacuated at 200°C for 12h under 1×10−5 Pa of vacuum. Raman scattering spectra were recorded using a Horiba Jobin–Yvon LabRAM 800HR micro-Raman spectrometer equipped with a He/Ne laser excitation source (632nm). Good spectral resolution was achieved using 50mW of transmitted laser power, integration time of 20s, and accumulation of 7 spectra. In situ XANES spectra at the V K-edge were measured in the region above 5420eV. The analyses were conducted at the XAFS1 beamline of the Brazilian Synchrotron Light laboratory (LNLS), in Campinas, Brazil. The XAFS1 beamline is equipped with a Si (111) monochromator operating in Bragg mode for selection of the desired range of X-ray wavelengths. The monochromator was calibrated by setting the first inflection point at the K-edge spectrum of a metallic vanadium foil standard at 5465eV. The samples were prepared in the form of self-supporting pellets composed of 20mg of non-calcined catalyst and 80mg of boron nitride (BN), and placed into a tubular quartz furnace, sealed with refrigerated kapton windows, for the transmission measurements. The calculated mass proportion of catalyst and BN ensured an edge jump of 1. The experiments consisted of in situ decomposition of the vanadium precursors during temperature-programmed oxidation under oxygen/nitrogen (20:80) flow during heating from room temperature to 500°C at a rate of 10°C/min. Analysis of the XANES data was performed with Athena graphical interface software. In the case of dynamic studies, three spectra were merged in order to improve the signal-to-noise ratio. The spectra were then normalized using the flattening algorithm in the default energy range used by Athena. Speciation of the vanadium species present during the in situ treatments was achieved by linear combination (LC) of the XANES spectra (from −20 to 120eV around the edge). Spectra for commercial VOSO4, NH4VO3, V2O3, V2O4, V2O5, and metallic vanadium foil were used as references. The acid sites of the catalysts were quantified by ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD). In all the experiments, 150mg of sample was degassed at 300°C for 1h under a flow of helium (60mL/min), and then cooled down to 100°C. At this temperature, the sample was exposed to a flow of 60mL/min of 1% ammonia in helium for 1h. After the adsorption of ammonia reached saturation, the sample was flushed with helium at 100°C for 1h to remove excess ammonia. The temperature was then increased to 600°C, at a rate of 10°C/min, under a flow of helium (60mL/min). The amount of ammonia desorbed per gram of sample was calculated from the mass spectrometer response. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out under flows of nitrogen or oxygen (100mL/min) using an SDT Q600 TGA/DSC thermobalance (TA Instruments). The sample was heated from 30 to 1000°C at a rate of 10°C/min. Information regarding the oxidation states of the fresh and spent vanadium oxide/MFI catalysts was obtained by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), using a commercial spectrometer (UNI-SPECS UHV). The Mg Kα line was used (1253.6eV), and the analyzer pass energy was set to 10eV. The binding energies of the V 2p3/2 core level spectra were corrected using the hydrocarbon component of adventitious carbon fixed at 285.0eV. The deconvoluted spectra were obtained using multiple Voigt profiles, without placing constraints. The width at half maximum (FWHM) varied between 1.5 and 2.2eV, and the accuracy of the peak positions was ±0.1eV. The 13C nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS NMR) analysis was performed using a Bruker Avance III 400MHz WB instrument, equipped with a 4mm probe and operated with a rotor speed of 15kHz. The spent catalysts (after the reaction) were placed into 4mm zirconia rotors, using the same volume of sample. The 13C NMR spectra were compared assuming the same bulk density for each sample and that the 13C signal was proportional to the amount of carbonaceous compounds deposited in the catalyst. The experimental conditions were a contact time of 2000s, a pulse width of 2.4s, and a frequency of 12kHz. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The oxidative dehydration of glycerol was carried out in the gas phase at 300, 320, and 350°C, under atmospheric pressure in a continuous-flow glass fixed-bed reactor. Prior to the catalytic tests, 100mg of the catalyst was heated to the reaction temperature under flows of nitrogen (30mL/min) or nitrogen/oxygen (24/6mL/min) and kept at this temperature for 15min before starting the reaction. Two thermocouples were used, one to monitor the oven temperature and the other placed in contact with the catalytic bed. Because of the exothermicity of the oxidation reaction, the reaction temperature was controlled by means of the second thermocouple. Glycerol was used as received (99wt.%, Sigma–Aldrich). The composition of the glycerol solution was 10wt.% in water, and the flow of this solution was controlled at 0.05mL/min using a continuous-flow syringe pump. The condensed products exiting the reactor were collected in a gas–liquid separator kept at 1°C, and analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a capillary column (Rtx-1, 30m, 0.32mm, 1μm) and FID detector. Before each injection, a known mass of n-butanol was added as internal standard. The analyses were performed in triplicate. The retention times were compared with those of authentic compounds. Quantification of all liquid products was achieved by comparison with calibration curves and the results were used to calculate the selectivity towards condensable products (C out/C in)·100. Selectivity towards condensable products of 100 means that unconverted glycerol and all liquid products exit the reactor. Selectivity towards condensable products less than 100 means that heavy products remain adsorbed on the catalyst surface, or are decomposed to CO and CO2 (not measured). Conversion of glycerol (X glycerol) and product selectivity (S i ) were calculated according to Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) X glycerol ( % ) = n Gl input − n Gl output n Gl input × 100 (2) S i ( % ) = n i n Gl input − n Gl output × Z i Z Gl × 100 where n Gl input and n Gl output are the input and output flows of glycerol (mol/min), n i is the flow of the products i (mol/min), Z Gl =3 (the number of carbon atoms in the glycerol molecule), and Z i represents the number of carbon atoms in the products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characteristics The X-ray powder diffraction patterns (Fig. 1 ) confirmed that the characteristic structure of the MFI zeolite was maintained after impregnation. The least intense peaks (marked with asterisks) corresponded to crystallites of V2O5 dispersed on the zeolite matrix. The Raman spectra of these samples (Fig. 2 ) provided complementary evidence that, regardless of the source of vanadium used for impregnation, the vanadium precursors were completely oxidized to the most stable V2O5 form. The Raman spectra of vanadium oxides show three different regions: V–O bending and lattice modes (below 400cm−1, due to crystalline V2O5), V–O–V stretching (400–800cm−1), and V–O stretching (800–1100cm−1). These three signals were evident in the spectra for the VAMFI and VBMFI samples, but were completely different, in terms of both intensity and position, compared to the spectra for the vanadium precursors VOSO4 and NH4VO3 [31–33]. The results of the in situ XANES analyses performed during heating of the MFI zeolites impregnated with vanadium precursors to 600°C are shown in Fig. 3 . The main feature in these XANES spectra is the pre-edge peak at around 5465eV, reflecting the dipole-forbidden 1s→3d transition, which becomes possible due to the removal of the inversion symmetry around the V atom. During the thermal treatment of the samples, a shift in the white line and a decrease of the shoulder located in the rising edge were observed, corresponding to oxidation of the vanadium salts to V2O5, according to Eqs. (3) and (4). (3) 2VOSO4 +1/2O2 →V2O5 +2SO3 (4) 2NH4VO3 →V2O5 +2NH3 +H2O Phase speciation of vanadium during the oxidation was performed by LC fitting of the spectra using spectra for relevant reference compounds, namely VOSO4, NH4VO3, V2O5 (thicker lines in Fig. 3A and C), V2O4, and V2O3. The absence of V2O4 during the thermal treatment provides further evidence that V2O5 was readily formed without the involvement of intermediate species, according to the reactions shown in Eqs. (3) and (4). Although there was no difference between the final compositions of the two catalysts, strong differences were observed concerning the temperature ranges in which decomposition of the precursors occurred. The decomposition of VOSO4 started at 200°C, with gradual conversion to V2O5 (Fig. 3B). On the other hand, the transformation of NH4VO3 started more abruptly, at 100°C, and at 350°C the proportion of V2O5 was nearly 100% (Fig. 3D). The Gibbs free energy of VOSO4 at 298K (ΔG 298 =−1169.85kJ/mol), compared to that of NH4VO3 (ΔH 298 =−888.26kJ/mol) [34], suggests greater thermal stability of VOSO4, as depicted in Fig. 3. The high-temperature decomposition of VOSO4 resulted in highly dispersed V2O5 in the VAMFI catalyst. Furthermore, NH4VO3 is a polyoxyanion whose decomposition can produce polymeric V2O5, leading to lower dispersion in the VBMFI catalyst. This behavior was reflected in the diffractograms (Fig. 1), where lower intensity peaks were observed for VAMFI due to the dispersion of V2O5 (reduced long-range order of V2O5), as well as in the higher nitrogen adsorption capacity of VAMFI (Fig. 4 ). As expected, the micropore volumes of the impregnated samples decreased, relative to the parent MFI zeolite, with values of 0.33cm3/g for the MFI zeolite, 0.26cm3/g for VAMFI, and 0.16cm3/g for VBMFI, despite the fact that all the materials had the same V/Al molar ratio (5.5). Additional information concerning the properties of the catalysts is provided in Table 1 . The EXAFS spectra and the Fourier transformed EXAFS signals for VAMFI and VBMFI (Fig. 5 ) were completely different, compared to the unsupported V2O5, reflecting the differences in the short-range structures of these oxides. At K values greater than 5, the spectra of the supported catalysts indicated a higher degree of disorder, in comparison to V2O5, because of dispersion on the zeolite surface. Although quantitative structural analysis was not performed, changes could be observed in the aggregation state of V2O5 dispersed on the zeolites, based on the local structure around vanadium atoms and on the long-range structural order observed by XRD. However, the EXAFS signals for samples VAMFI and VBMFI (Fig. 5) showed that there were only small differences in the short-range order. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia was used to determine the strength and distribution of the surface acidity of the solid catalysts. The V2O5 oxide showed low acidity, with 0.8μmol of adsorbed ammonia per gram of catalyst, mainly due to the presence of weak Lewis acid sites (peak “l” in Fig. 6 ). As expected, the MFI zeolite exhibited a high temperature desorption signal at 450°C (peak “h”), due to Brønsted acid sites, with acidity corresponding to 3.5μmol of adsorbed ammonia per gram. An interesting feature of the TPD results was the substantial increase in low temperature desorption of ammonia, in the case of the impregnated samples. The VAMFI and VBMFI catalysts showed acidities of 10.8 and 4.9μmol/g, respectively. A possible explanation for the higher Lewis acidity of VAMFI could be the greater dispersion obtained by impregnation using VOSO4. The intensities of high temperature desorption of ammonia from the VAMFI and VBMFI catalysts were similar to the signal obtained for the parent zeolite; however, a slight shift to lower temperature was observed, showing that the presence of V2O5 in the zeolite reduced the strength of the Brønsted acid sites [35,36]. 3.2 Glycerol oxidehydration reaction The vanadium oxide-impregnated zeolites were studied for the oxidative dehydration of glycerol to acrylic acid. The bifunctional VAMFI and VBMFI catalysts prepared in this study provided glycerol conversion of up to 97%, and selectivity towards acrylic acid was close to 17% under an N2/O2 atmosphere. Other important chemicals were also produced, including acrolein and acetaldehyde (Fig. 7 ). Although acrylic acid was produced on pure V2O5, the conversion of glycerol was very low, even at temperatures as high as 350°C, and higher selectivity towards acetic acid was observed. The rate-determining step appeared to be the dehydration of glycerol to acrolein, because pure vanadium oxides do not present sufficient acidity to perform this reaction, resulting in an imbalance, with more oxidant active sites than acid sites. The conversion was much higher for the parent MFI zeolite, although the main product was acrolein. The VAMFI catalyst provided high glycerol conversion and high selectivity towards acrylic acid at 300°C, due to a combination of both acid and oxidant catalytic sites. Furthermore, the micropore volume for VAMFI was around 40% higher than for VBMFI (Table 1), despite the fact that the two catalysts had the same V/Al molar ratios (5.5). In this case, differences in the kinetics of decomposition of the vanadium precursors resulted in slightly better dispersion of V2O5 in the VAMFI catalyst [37,38]. Although the dispersion of V2O5 on the zeolites favored the number of Lewis acid sites (indicated by the NH3 desorption profiles in Fig. 6), it seems that the stronger zeolite Brønsted acid sites were mainly responsible for the conversion of glycerol to acrolein. In an earlier systematic study of desilicated zeolites, it was shown that increased formation of less acidic Lewis acid sites on the zeolites did not contribute to the overall glycerol conversion [11]. Therefore, even with the differences in Lewis acid sites, the greatest contribution of vanadium oxide in the V-MFI catalysts was in the oxidation step. The formation of acrylic acid using the VAMFI catalyst was enhanced by increasing the reaction temperature from 300 to 320°C, and then to 350°C. The lower activity under an N2 atmosphere indicated the importance of oxygen for the selective conversion of glycerol. In these catalytic reactions, the vanadium oxide species oxidize the acrolein intermediate by means of the Mars–Van-Krevelen redox cycle, using mobile lattice oxygen [39,40], so a feed of molecular oxygen into the inflowing gas stream is required for optimal performance. Two aspects of these bifunctional catalysts seem to be important: the quantity of acrolein that is chemisorbed on the oxide surface, and the good dispersion of vanadium oxide on the zeolite, which results in instability of the surface atoms and enables easy shifts between the V4+ and V5+ oxidation states during the catalytic cycles. Fig. 8 shows the results of thermogravimetric analysis under an air atmosphere, comparing commercial V2O4, V2O5, and spent V2O5 catalysts after 1h of use in the glycerol oxidehydration reaction. At temperature close to 350°C, there was a substantial increase of the mass of the spent V2O5 catalyst, due to the oxidation of reduced V2O x oxides according to Eq. (5). The fresh V2O5 remained unchanged during the thermogravimetric experiment, as expected. This finding reinforces the need for a reaction temperature of 350°C and the presence of air to promote the formation of acrylic acid, due to the dynamic reduction/oxidation of the active sites involved in selective oxidation of acrolein. (5) V 2 O x + 1 / 2 O 2 → V 2 O 5 In order to confirm this redox behavior, the VAMFI catalyst was analyzed using XPS. The dynamic shifts between V5+ and V4+ resulting from the catalytic cycles were analyzed by means of changes in the binding energy of V 2p3/2 (Fig. 9 ). The low contribution of surface V4+ (20%) in the fresh catalyst increased to 55% after 8h of use in a glycerol stream at 300°C. After thermal treatment at 350°C for 1h under an air atmosphere, the V5+ surface concentration recovered to the initial amount (80%). According to some authors [42,43], the surface and near-surface presence of V4+ in calcined catalyst results from combined exposure to air and water vapor. Chemical analysis of the surface layer, based on a depth of a few monolayers (which is inherent to XPS analysis), revealed a Si/Al molar ratio of 37, which was quite close to the composition of the zeolite framework. However, the V/Al molar ratio was only 3.4, which was very different to the nominal value of 5.5. This divergence in vanadium composition reinforces the findings of the XRD, XAS, and N2 physisorption analyses, with the vanadium species being dispersed not only on the external surface of the zeolite, but also a few monolayers deep, inside the pores. 3.3 Positive effect of vanadium oxide on catalyst stability and suppression of carbon deposits The glycerol dehydration step can be performed separately from the oxidation by employing a two-bed reactor approach [7]. However, a potential advantage of bifunctional catalysts contained in a single catalytic bed, in which the different active sites are mixed together, is their better long-term performance. Glycerol dehydration on acid sites forms acrolein, which is readily further activated to produce carbon deposits by oligomerization. This explains the strong drop in activity of the parent MFI zeolite [7]. However, the presence of vanadium oxides near zeolite acid sites enabled achievement of continuous oxidation of undesired dehydration byproducts. The temporal behavior was analyzed for MFI (Fig. 10A) and VAMFI (Fig. 10B). After 8h, the catalytic conversion capability of the bifunctional VAMFI catalyst remained unchanged, while the MFI catalyst became deactivated by the deposition of carbonaceous compounds. As expected, the selectivity to condensable products was lower for the VAMFI catalyst due to formation of acetaldehyde, acetic acid, and major oxidation products, with release of CO and CO2. For a reaction lasting 8h, the average selectivity to condensable products was 56% for the MFI catalyst and 30% for VAMFI. However, more valuable acrylic acid was formed on VAMFI, and the glycerol conversion was stable at approximately 98%. The oxidation of carbon deposits was enhanced by the dispersion of vanadium oxides in the VAMFI catalyst, which created a different environment in terms of aggregation and oxidation states of the vanadium species involved in the selective conversion of glycerol. The unique design of this multifunctional catalyst therefore enabled control of the balance between coke formation and selective glycerol oxidation over an extended period. Thermogravimetric analysis (Fig. 11A) was used to quantify the formation of carbon species during the reaction. Considering the temperature range between 400 and 650°C, related to the loss of carbonaceous compounds, the MFI zeolite used in the reaction at 300°C showed a mass loss of 9.8%, while for the same reaction temperature, the VAMFI catalyst showed a mass loss of 4.7%. When the reaction temperature was increased, the mass losses obtained for the VAMFI catalyst were 5.7% at 320°C and 6.5% at 350°C. Therefore, despite the fact that higher temperatures favored the formation of acrylic acid, greater production of carbonaceous compounds was also observed. Although CO and CO2 was not measured during the catalytic tests, a stoichiometric analysis of the thermogravimetric curves of the spent catalysts helped us to estimate their contribution to the overall carbon balance. Considering the first 1h of reaction of the VAMFI catalyst, the selectivity to condensable products was of 30%, while the oxidation of carbonaceous compounds deposited on the catalyst corresponded only to 6.5% of the fed glycerol. Therefore, more than 60% of the carbon atoms outflowing the reactor are made of very volatile or incondensable products, such as CO and CO2. The DTG curves (Fig. 11B) for the samples impregnated with vanadium oxides showed a shift to lower temperatures in the region corresponding to the decomposition of carbonaceous compounds, due to a change in the nature of the carbon. Martin [44], Schüth [45], and Znaiguia et al. [46] reported that two families of carbon species could occur. This finding was based on two decomposition events that were apparent in the thermogravimetric curves for spent catalysts used in glycerol transformation. However, not much evidence concerning the composition of the carbon was provided, with the exception of identification of the presence of polyaromatics [46]. Finally, the mass increases associated with the oxidation of V4+ to V5+ during the TG analysis were not detectable (Fig. 11C), because the quantity of vanadium in the V-MFI catalysts was relatively low, compared to the pure oxide. However, the DTA curves showed an exothermic shoulder at around 350°C, corresponding to the oxidation of vanadium, while the V2O5 melting point was indicated by an endothermic event near 650°C. Curiously, although the amount of carbon species deposited on the VAMFI zeolite was close to 5wt.%, the catalyst did not show any decrease in glycerol conversion, up to 8h. All the catalysts became coked to greater or lesser extents, as evidenced by the black appearance of the samples after the catalytic tests. The most plausible explanation for the effectiveness of the VMFI catalysts lies in a shift to less harmful types of carbonaceous deposits. The use of 13C NMR spectroscopy enabled the detection of changes in the composition of heavy molecules deposited on the catalyst surfaces. Fig. 12 compares the liquid NMR spectrum for glycerol, where very thin peaks reflect the high mobility of the molecules, with spectra for the spent catalysts, which show the broad peaks associated with bulky and less mobile molecules. Two families of carbon deposits could be identified for the spent catalysts: (1) peaks at δ higher than 130ppm were attributed to polyaromatic compounds, and peaks at δ =19 and 35ppm to saturated carbon atoms of terminal chains bound to these oligomeric compounds; (2) peaks at δ =63 and 70ppm were attributed to polyglycol compounds (branched oxygen-containing carbonaceous deposits). The mechanism of polyaromatics formation (type 1) involves the accumulation of complex or monomeric surface species during the glycerol dehydration, followed by their transport and oligomerization inside zeolite pores. In this type of carbon deposition, not only are the active sites covered, but the micropores are also blocked. The vanadium oxide species clearly helped in the inhibition of these oligomers, as evidenced by their smaller peaks in the 13C NMR spectra and by the micropore volumes of the spent catalysts. The VAMFI and MFI zeolites showed reductions of microporosity from 0.26 to 0.14mL/g and from 0.33 to 0mL/g, respectively (Table 1). On the other hand, the pathway of polyether formation (type 2) involves the intermolecular dehydration of glycerol molecules activated on the outer surface and neighboring acid sites (Brønsted acid sites associated with the zeolite framework), followed by the successive coupling of hydroxyl groups of glycerol. Fig. 13 outlines a possible step involved in its formation. Different to the formation of polyaromatics, the formation of polyglycols involves the association of bulky polycondensed molecules, resulting in preferential formation on the outer surfaces of the zeolites. This type of coke is probably the most harmful, because it obstructs the entry of reactants into the zeolite pores, and consequently prevents access to the active sites. The zeolite therefore shows an immediate drop in catalytic activity, although the innermost sites remain active. Similar formation of ether is observed in the dehydration of simple alcohols such as ethanol on zeolite acidic sites, with formation of diethyl ether due to intermolecular dehydration [41]. Nevertheless, in the case of glycerol, the existence of three hydroxyl groups leads to the formation of less volatile poly-branched ether molecules. For the vanadium-impregnated zeolites, an interesting finding was that the polyether peaks at 70–63ppm disappeared, because the external acid sites of the zeolites were protected by coverage with vanadium oxide species. This loss of strong Brønsted acid sites was evidenced by the decrease of peak “h” in Fig. 6. 3.4 Comparison of performance with earlier catalytic systems for glycerol oxidehydration Materials based on vanadium oxide are among the most active and selective oxidation catalysts, due to their capacity to adopt multiple oxidation states. Table 2 lists the results obtained for glycerol oxidehydration to acrylic acid using several different vanadium-based catalysts, where pure V2O5 converted only 40% of glycerol to 5% of acrylic acid. In order to obtain more reducible and more accessible active sites, and therefore improve the efficiency of one-step glycerol oxidehydration, the properties of vanadium oxides need to be altered by dispersion in suitable supports or by incorporation of other additives. On one hand, the preparation of vanadium/tungsten mixed oxides enhances the acid properties of the catalyst and therefore diminishes the rate-limiting glycerol dehydration. On the other hand, catalytic activity can be enhanced by using vanadium/molybdenum mixed oxides, because the combination of the two elements facilitates the dynamic changes of V5+/V4+ oxidation states during the catalytic reaction. This is the reason for the outstanding catalytic activity observed for the mixed V/W/Nb oxide catalysts prepared by López Nieto [22,28], with yields of up to 50% acrylic acid. These results indicate that the development of methods that provide good dispersion of the active sites on acid matrices is essential, because the resulting catalysts can favor the conversion of glycerol to acrolein and induce efficient redox cycling of vanadium oxides. 4 Conclusions The properties of bifunctional V2O5/MFI catalysts were investigated for the conversion of glycerol to acrolein and then to acrylic acid. Raman and XANES spectra showed that the final product resulting from the decomposition of vanadium salts was V2O5 for both VAMFI and VBMFI catalysts. However, the two catalysts showed different behavior in the glycerol oxidehydration reaction. The activity of the VAMFI catalyst and its selectivity towards acrylic acid were associated with greater dispersion of V2O5, as revealed by nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms and NH3-TPD. The use of a temperature of 350°C and an N2/O2 atmosphere enabled the dynamic oxidation and reduction of vanadium oxides in a Mars–Van-Krevelen redox cycle, with lattice oxygen as reactive intermediate. The zeolite Brønsted acid sites gave rise to two families of carbonaceous deposits that were identified as polyaromatics and bulky polycondensed polyglycol molecules. The advantages of the multifunctional VAMFI catalyst include the bifunctional conversion of glycerol to acrylic acid, as well as the presence of vanadium oxides near the acid sites, which inhibits the formation of monomers of carbonaceous species before they can oligomerize and block access to the catalyst. coredata.dc:description: The catalytic behavior of bifunctional V2O5/MFI catalysts with acid and oxidizing properties was investigated for the gas-phase oxidehydration of glycerol. One of the main reaction products was acrylic acid, produced by dehydration of glycerol to acrolein at an acidic site and subsequent oxidation at a redox site. Comparison of wet impregnation with vanadyl sulfate (VOSO4) and ammonium metavanadate (NH4VO3) showed that VOSO4 impregnation provided the best performance for the conversion of glycerol and selectivity towards acrylic acid. The chemical and structural properties of the catalysts were studied by X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms, Raman spectroscopy, temperature programmed ammonia desorption, and X-ray absorption spectroscopy in the XANES region for the K-edge absorption of vanadium. XPS measurements of the fresh and spent catalysts enabled elucidation of the dynamic redox cycles of vanadium oxide during oxidation of acrolein. The presence of vanadium in the zeolite improved the catalyst lifetime, because of the multifunctional ability of the vanadium oxide species to convert acrolein to acrylic acid and act as co-catalyst for the oxidation of coked glycerol products. Qualitative and quantitative analyses of the coke deposited in the spent catalysts were performed using 13C NMR and thermogravimetry, respectively.
coredata.dc:title: One-step glycerol oxidehydration to acrylic acid on multifunctional zeolite catalysts
